The journey of the Wheel-Treasure [dn17:: The wheel-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana
The king besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand
The wheel-treasure rolled towards the east
The king followed it together with his army of four divisions
In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army
Any opposing rulers of the eastern quarter came to him and became his vassals
The wheel-treasure rolled towards the south
The wheel-treasure rolled towards the west
The wheel-treasure rolled towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions
In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army
Any opposing rulers of the northern quarter came to him and became his vassals
The wheel-treasure returned to the royal capital of Kusāvatī and stood still by the gate to Mahāsudassana’s royal compound at the High Court.
The qualities of the counselor-treasure: Capable of getting the king to appoint who should be appointed
Capable of dismissing who should be dismissed
Capable of retaining who should be retained
The four blessings possessed by King Mah: Attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty
Rarely ill or unwell, and his stomach digested well, being neither too hot nor too cold
As dear and beloved to the brahmins and householders as a father is to his children, and the brahmins and householders were as dear to the king as children are to their father
The lotus ponds in the Palace of Princip: King Mahāsudassana thought of having lotus ponds built between the palms, at intervals of a hundred bow lengths
The lotus ponds were lined with tiles of four colors, made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal
Four flights of stairs of four colors descended into each lotus pond, made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal
The lotus ponds were surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver
Flowers such as blue water lilies, and lotuses of pink, yellow, and white were planted in the lotus ponds
Bath attendants were appointed to help bathe the people who come to bathe in the lotus ponds
Charities were set up on the banks of the lotus ponds, so that those in need of food, drink, clothes, vehicles, beds, women, gold, or silver can get what they need
The Palace of Principle (a causal sequen: King Mahāsudassana thought of having a palace built for him
The brahmins and householders brought abundant wealth to the king, but he turned them down
They decided to build a home for King Mahāsudassana
Sakka, lord of gods, asked the god Vissakamma to build a palace named Principle as a home for King Mahāsudassana
Vissakamma built the Palace of Principle
The Palace of Principle was lined with tiles of four colors, made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal
It had 84,000 pillars of four colors, made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal
It had twenty-four staircases of four colors, made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal
It had 84,000 chambers of four colors, made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal
The Palace of Principle was surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver
It was surrounded by two nets of bells, made of gold and silver
It was surrounded by seven rows of palm trees, made of gold, silver, beryl, crystal, ruby, emerald, and all precious things
The four absorptions [dn17:2.1.0]: First absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected
Second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected
Third absorption, where he meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
Fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
The four meditations (a causal sequence): Spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth
Spreading a heart full of compassion
Spreading a heart full of rejoicing
Spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.

84,000 palaces, with the Palace of Principle foremost
84,000 chambers, with the great foyer foremost
84,000 couches made of gold, silver, ivory, and hardwood
84,000 bull elephants with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the royal bull elephant named Sabbath foremost
84,000 horses with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the royal steed named Thundercloud foremost
84,000 chariots upholstered with the hide of lions, tigers, and leopards, and cream rugs, with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the chariot named Triumph foremost
84,000 jewels, with the jewel-treasure foremost
84,000 women, with Queen Subhaddā foremost
84,000 householders, with the householder-treasure foremost
84,000 aristocrat vassals, with the counselor-treasure foremost
84,000 milk-cows with silken reins and bronze pails
8,400,000,000 fine cloths of linen, cotton, silk, and wool
84,000 servings of food, which were presented to him as offerings in the morning and evening.
The elephants attending on King Mahāsuda: His 84,000 royal elephants came to attend on him in the morning and evening
He instructed the counselor-treasure to have half of the elephants take turns to attend on him at the end of each century.
She addressed the ladies of the harem, asking them to bathe their heads and dress in yellow
She addressed the counselor-treasure, asking him to ready the army of four divisions
She went with the army to the Palace of Principle
She ascended the palace and went to the great foyer, where she stood leaning against a door-post
She urged the king to live on by taking an interest in all his possessions
She cried and burst out in tears

The words spoken by the king and Queen S: Queen Subhaddā urged the king to live on by taking an interest in all his possessions
The king corrected her and told her to give up desire for all his possessions
Queen Subhaddā cried and burst out in tears
She then spoke the words that the king had corrected her with, urging him to give up desire for all his possessions.
